title: radiation
body:
An emanation of hazardous electromagnetic energy.

In media, it is often stereotypically depicted as green gas or ooze. A more realistic depiction would be a blue or purple haze/glow around the emitting object, to represent the ionization of the surrounding air and/or [[Cherenkov radiation]] caused by extremely radioactive objects or [[film grain]] from the exposure of radiation on a camera lens. An artistic representation may be stylized "rays" coming from this object.

h4. See also

* [[Cherenkov radiation]]
* [[demon core]]

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Radiation":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radiation

title: tiefling
body:
A tiefling is a fictional humanoid race introduced by the [[Dungeons & Dragons]] tabletop role-playing game. They are described as "human-based planetouched, native outsiders that were infused with the touch of the fiendish planes (typically devils)"

They are essentially [[demon girl]]s and [[demon boy|boys]]. They typically have e.g. [[demon horns|horns]] and a [[demon tail|tail]], and atypically [[colored skin]] (e.g. [[red skin|red]], [[pink skin|pink]], [[purple skin|purple]], or [[black skin|jet black]]).

title: drawcrowd_sample
body:
An [[image sample]] from Drawcrowd.

Drawcrowd does not work with the bookmarklet and you must manually alter part of the image URL (typically [b]/large/[/b]) to [b]/original/[/b]. The download and expand buttons on Drawcrowd are deceptive in that the original is usually kept hidden to mitigate bandwidth costs. If the [b]/original/[/b] returns a [b]file not found[/b] error, then the [b]/large/[/b] image is accepted as the original.

It is Danbooru policy to either replace samples or delete them. See [[image sample]] for more information. See [[howto:drawcrowd]] for how to upload images from Drawcrowd correctly.

h4. See also

* [[Bad Drawcrowd ID]]

title: deviantart_sample
body:
An [[image sample]] from DeviantArt.

DeviantArt image URLs sometimes contain either the string "200H" or "PRE". These URLs point to scaled down images, not the full size. 200H URLs point to small thumbnails, scaled down to 200 pixels. PRE URLs point to medium-sized samples, displayed on the art page by default if the full-sized image is too large. If you remove the "200H/" or "PRE/" parts from one of these sample URLs, the resulting URL will point to the full-sized version instead.

This tag should be used when the image uploaded to Danbooru is one of these scaled down versions.

It is Danbooru policy to either replace samples or delete them. See [[image sample]] for more information. See [[howto:deviantart]] for how to upload from DeviantArt correctly.

h4. See also

* [[Bad DeviantArt ID]]

title: tumblr_sample
body:
An [[image sample]] from Tumblr.

Tumblr images carry one of multiple available file name suffixes: 

* [code]_75sq[/code] (sample; thumbnail)
* [code]_100[/code] (sample; thumbnail)
* [code]_250[/code] (sample)
* [code]_400[/code] (sample)
* [code]_500[/code] (sample; sometimes original, see forum #132817)
* [code]_500h[/code] (sample; height-bounded)
* [code]_540[/code] (sample)
* [code]_640[/code] (sample)
* [code]_1280[/code] (sample; sometimes original)
* [code]_raw[/code] (defunct)

It is Danbooru policy to either replace samples or delete them. See [[image sample]] for more information. See [[howto:tumblr]] on how to upload from Tumblr correctly.

h4. See also

* [[Bad Tumblr ID]]

title: artstation_sample
body:
An [[image sample]] from ArtStation.

An ArtStation sample can either have lower image dimensions, or have the same dimensions but truncated bit-by-bit quality.

ArtStation formerly had a much more complicated image sampling issue, which can be referred back to by looking at previous revisions of this article or viewing the legacy procedure for avoiding samples at [[howto:artstation]]. Now a user may errantly upload from image URLs including "/small/" or "/medium/" rather than the correct "/large/" which would be replaceable by a moderator or by uploading the unsampled version and manually deleting the sample. There was formerly a fourth "/original/" which was manually accessible to save bandwidth. ArtStation terminated access to such files reportedly also to save bandwidth.

h4. See also

* [[Bad ArtStation ID]]

title: a-pose
body:
A pose shaped like the capital letter "A", where the arms are held straight out and angled downwards from the sides of the body.

This is more relaxed than a [[T-pose]] or [[outstretched arms]], but less relaxed than [[arms at sides]] where the arms simply hang against the torso due to gravity.

You often see this pose in a few contexts, for example:

* A character showing off an outfit.
* A character posed similarly to a [[Sailor Moon]] magical-girl style [[transformation]] scene or the like where the character appears to be relaxed, but floating.

The name comes from 3D modelling as an alternative to the more common [[T-pose]].  The A-pose allows for the shoulders to be modeled and textured in a more natural position, and the defined angle can aid in rigging.

h4. Related tags

h6. Larger angle

* [[T-pose]]
* [[outstretched arms]]
* [[airplane arms]]
* [[spread arms]]

h6. Smaller angle

* [[Arms at sides]]
* [[v arms]] (arms point inward towards body center)

h4. See also

* [[w arms]] (arms can either point inward or outward, but with forearms raised)
* [[Tag Group:Posture]]

h4. External links

* "Discussion of T-pose vs A-pose":https://polycount.com/discussion/202303/to-t-pose-or-not-to-t-pose
* "Discussion of T-pose vs A-pose (in Japanese)":https://itami.info/tech/3d/a-pose-or-t-pose.html

title: panty_mask
body:
Wearing [[panties]] on the face like a [[mask]].

This is a common comedic gag for characters portrayed as [[pervert]]s (either canonically or in fan-based memes), or those that engage in [[underwear theft]].  Common culprits featuring this situation include [[Akemi Homura]] and [[Hentai Kamen]] and [[Kajou Ayame]] (as [[Blue Snow]]), who both feature this as part of their [[costume]]s.

This is typically shown as the panties being wrapped around the whole of the head (see post #912795, post #1021602) with the crotch of the panties covering the mouth and nose of the wearer, the waistband around the top of the head and chin, and the wearer's ears protruding through the leg holes, securing the sides of the waist band.

Other methods also exist, where the top of the waistband crosses below the wearer's eyes (see post #4082406, post #3944133).  This form better evokes the form of a [[mouth mask]] and seems to have become more common in response to the [[coronavirus pandemic]] of 2020.

Other variations can exist (e.g. post #3308317, post #1717051, post #65772). This tag is applicable so long as the face is largely involved, and the panties aren't simply worn on the top of the head like a [[hat]], with the waistband around the forehead.  [[Panties on head]] covers both cases, and is implicated by this tag.

For the converse of this tag, where a [[mouth mask]] is worn over the crotch as if they were [[panties]], use the tag [[mask panties]].

h4. See also

* [[Hentai Kamen]]
* [[Blue Snow]]
* [[panties on head]]
* [[mask panties]]
* [[mask bikini]]

title: roto_(dq3)
body:
The hero in [[Dragon Quest III]]. While the game gave a choice to play a male or female hero, the sprite used was the same. Thus the female hero is often drawn [[androgynous]] in fan art. Nevertheless the [[genderswap]] tag does not apply here. In the remakes of the game, there are different sprites for the male and female versions of Roto.

Note that "Roto" is a title more than anything else, given to the greatest of heroes in Alefgard. The hero became Roto at the very end of the game, after saving the underworld (Alefgard) by defeating [[Zoma]]. They would later become the ancestor of the [[Dragon quest i|DQ1]] and [[Dragon quest ii|DQ2]] heroes.

In English translations, aside from a brief stint as [b]"Loto"[/b], the title has been consistently translated as [b]"Erdrick"[/b], used in the original NES translation of the first game.

He (that is, the [[hero (dq3)|male hero]]), along with the heroes of [i][[hero (dq4)|IV]][/i], [i][[hero (dq8)|VIII]][/i] and [i][[hero (dq11)|XI]][/i], was chosen to be a fighter on [[super smash bros.|Super Smash Bros. Ultimate]]'s first fighters pass. They are collectively Fighter #72, with Eleven as the "face".

h4. See also

* [[Hero (DQ3)]]  [tn]Roto when depicted as male[/tn]
* [[Heroine (DQ3)]] [tn]Roto when depicted as female[/tn]
* [[Arihara Yuuna (hanauna)|]]

title: heroine_(dq3)
body:
The female form of [[Roto (dq3)|]], the hero and protagonist of [[Dragon Quest III]].

In the game, the player designates the character as either male or female.  Originally, the [[sprite]] used was the same regardless of this choice. Even as a female, the hero is often drawn [[androgynous]]ly or as a [[tomboy]] in fan art (with e.g. notably [[short hair]]). Use this tag when it is clear (e.g. by presence of [[breasts]] or other well-defined sexual characteristics or activities) that the artist intended for this iteration of Roto to be female.

h4. See also

* [[Roto (dq3)|]]
* [[Hero (DQ3)]] [tn]Roto, when depicted as a male.[/tn]
* [[Arihara yuuna (hanauna)|]] [tn]A specific long-haired original character based on the female version of Roto that has diverged and can be considered a separate character.[/tn]

title: marl_kingdom
body:
A trilogy of role playing video games developed by [[Nippon Ichi]] for the Playstation and Playstation 2. The games are as follows:

* [[Rhapsody]], released for Playstation in 1998, and was the only one to be localized. Although popular in Japan, its girlish elements didn't appeal to the western audience.
* [[Little Princess]], released for Playstation in 1999, then made available for download on the Playstation 3 and Playstation Portable via the Playstation Store.
* Tenshi no Present, released for Playstation 2 in 2000. This game isn't tagged since it is just a collection of side stories relating to the previous two games.

title: ichido_dake_demo_koukai_shitemasu
body:
A [[yuri]] manga about a landlady and her tenant.

Kozuka Chiyo (the tenant) has been unemployed, her rent is 3 months behind and all of her saving have been spent on beers. One day, the landlady comes to Kozuka with an offer: whenever Kozuka do something she like, she'll tick off a box to reduce the remaining money which Kozuka is still owed, until all of the boxes are ticked or all of the remaining owed money is paid.

title: terada_tera_(style)
body:
Artwork [[style parody|parodying the style]] of [[Terada Tera]], often that of characters designed for the music videos of songs written by [[NayutalieN]] and sung by Nanawo Akari.

The common features of this style include notably [[chibi]] proportions with large [[jitome]] or [[upturned eyes]] with small pupils (sometimes bordering on [[slit pupils]]) and flat shading.

In the meme, the drawings are typically replaced with material for pool #4229 (Perversion of Canon).

h4. External links

title: skirt_as_blanket_(meme)
body:
A [[meme]] started on Twitter by artist [[Raya (yuri15923)]] in June 2024.

It is a [[2koma]] format comic with the first panel depicting one character [[sleeping]] with their [[head on table|head on a table]], with another character seeming to be [[covering with blanket|tucking them in]] gently with a blanket.  The second panel indicates that the "blanket" is actually the sleeping character's [[skirt lift|skirt]] which is being [[lifting another's clothes|lifted]] resulting in [[assisted exposure]].

Because of this, it generally falls into pool #2278 (Almost Heart-Warming) territory, and could be considered [[bait and switch]].

h4. Origin

* !post #7741409

h4. External links

* "Know Your Meme: Skirt as Blanket":[https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/skirt-as-blanket]

body:

They take the form of [[green skin|green-skinned]] [[zombie|zombified]] versions of the [[common cell (hataraku saibou)|]] mob characters.  As such they are typically all male, have [[spiked hair|spiked]] [[black hair]], and wear [[white shirt|white]] [[t-shirt]]s and [[black pants]]. Up close, their eyes have [[no pupils]], and on their heads they wear a round [[red headwear|red]] [[hat]]-like cap with white spikey bits poking out of it representing the virion itself.

title: anata_horuko
body:
An [[original]] moe character designed by [[yucchi_(kotoba_zombie)]] and belonging to "Zest-System":[https://www.zest-system.com/], a company that appears to do graphics design, signage, and light construction.

The character was designed to be used in [[warning sign]]s for the construction industry (e.g. "do not enter").  The character carries a shovel and her name could be read something along the lines of: "Holefield Digger" which fits her purpose.

For some reason a handful of artists on Twitter and Pixiv apparently found her cute and started drawing her, despite a stern warning in Zest-System's catalogue not to use their characters.

She is a [[tomboy]]-like character with [[brown eyes]], [[short_hair|short]] [[messy hair|messy]] [[brown hair]] sometimes with an [[ahoge]].  She wears a [[blue shirt|blue]] [[camisole]], [[green_pants|green]] [[cargo pants|cargo]] [[pants]], and a [[brown belt]], she also sometimes carries a [[shovel]].

h4. External links

* "Zest-System's catalogue":[https://online.pubhtml5.com/iokx/trra/#p=170] showing products featuring Anata Horuko.
* "Twitter: #穴田ほるこ":[https://twitter.com/search?q=穴田ほるこ] - Anata Horuko's hashtag on Twitter
* "Twitter: Photo of Anata Horuko's 'Do not enter' sign being used publically":[https://twitter.com/aliceonthethigh/status/1426915647733125124]

title: shrink_wrap
body:
A plastic film that is used to wrap something (very often a product for sale).

When heat is applied to it, it shrinks to conform to the product inside. This is often done to hold food onto a [[tray]] in [[food packaging]], or when done to another [[container]] (such as a [[medicine]] [[box]], [[cd case]], or [[video game]] [[box]]) to be tamper-evident for safety or prevent theft. It is also used on [[book]]s and [[manga (object)|]] either to prevent minors from viewing adult content or to prevent shoppers from reading in a store without purchasing.

title: robot_(manabi_kangaeru_rekishi)_(meme)
body:
For the original robot character, see [[Robot (Manabi Kangaeru Rekishi)]].

Around May 2024, a [[meme]] featuring [[Robot (Manabi Kangaeru Rekishi)]] spread on X (formerly Twitter) where this robot would make insensitive comments on various people and situations without reading the room, and became a popular joke format.  In this meme form, the robot has been called "ノンデリロボ" / "Indelicate Robot", "鬼畜ロボ" / "Brutal Robot", "ロボカス" / "Robo-Trash", or simply "例のロボ" / "That Certain Robot" among other things.  In this meme format, the robot typically says a phrase ending in "...ばいいのに" / "It's still fine even if..."

h4. Examples

* !asset #21721862

h4. External links

* "Pixiv Encyclopedia: Robot (Manabi Kangaeru Rekishi)":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C%E3%83%83%E3%83%88(%E5%AD%A6%E3%81%B3%E8%80%83%E3%81%88%E3%82%8B%E6%AD%B4%E5%8F%B2)]
* "Pixiv Encyclopedia: Indelicate Robot":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%8E%E3%83%B3%E3%83%87%E3%83%AA%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C]
* "Pixiv Encyclopedia: Robo-Trash":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C%E3%82%AB%E3%82%B9]
* "The meme on Twitter/X":[https://x.com/search?q=%E4%BE%8B%E3%81%AE%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C]
other_names: ロボット(学び考える歴史)

title: robot_(manabi_kangaeru_rekishi)
body:
A small blue [[robot]] with a round head with a [[radio antenna|antenna]] on top and a cylindrical body with a [[?|question mark]] on it. It was featured in the middle school history textbook entitled "Manabi Kangaeru Rekishi" / "History to Learn and Think About".

It doesn't have an officially set name and is simply referred to as "Robot". It is has also been known as the Impression-Tweeting Robot or the Textbook Robot.

Its appearance is meant to be that of a very ordinary robot that would be likely to appear in educational media, but and meant to have the trait of "having and amazing memory but not to know much about humans".

In the textbook, the robot repeatedly makes remarks about historical events based on modern values, disregarding the historical context and religious views of the time, which could be taken as provocative. Its non-robotic, uncharacteristically cynical, and brutish behavior has garnered mysterious attention and become a topic of discussion.

Around May 2024, [[robot_(manabi_kangaeru_rekishi)_(meme)|a meme featuring this character]] spread on X (formerly Twitter) where this robot would make insensitive comments on various people and situations without reading the room, and became a popular joke format.  In this meme form, the robot has been called "ノンデリロボ" / "Indelicate Robot", "鬼畜ロボ" / "Brutal Robot", "ロボカス" / "Robo-Trash", or simply "例のロボ" / "That Certain Robot" among other things.  In this meme format, the robot typically says a phrase ending in "...ばいいのに" / "It's still fine even if..."

h4. Appearance

* !asset #21721862

h4. See also

* [[Robot (Manabi Kangaeru Rekishi) (meme)]]

h4. External links

* "Pixiv Encyclopedia - Robot (Manabi Kangaeru Rekishi)":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C%E3%83%83%E3%83%88(%E5%AD%A6%E3%81%B3%E8%80%83%E3%81%88%E3%82%8B%E6%AD%B4%E5%8F%B2)]
* "Pixiv Encyclopedia - Indelicate Robot":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%8E%E3%83%B3%E3%83%87%E3%83%AA%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C]
* "Pixiv Encyclopedia - Robo-Trash":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C%E3%82%AB%E3%82%B9]
* "The meme on Twitter/X":[https://x.com/search?q=%E4%BE%8B%E3%81%AE%E3%83%AD%E3%83%9C]

title: open-bust_leotard
body:
A type of [[leotard]] that became popular in the 1980s as part of the [[aerobics]] fashion craze at the time.

As the name suggests, unlike most leotards, this garnment does not cover the chest and instead only features straps that come up from the waist to the shoulders, similar to a [[slingshot swimsuit]] with a leotard bottom.  This type of leotard is also always [[sleeveless]]. It is intended to be worn with a [[shirt]] or two (often a [[crop top]] or bandeau) above and/or beneath it.

This differs from [[breastless leotard]] which is a type of lingerie or erotic-wear intended to leave the breasts exposed, and is usually cut differently (sometimes omitting the straps altogether or combining them into a halterneck).

h4. Examples

* !post #5600396
* !post #5406426: (center)

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Leotard (Crossover to fashion activewear)":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leotard#Crossover_to_fashion_activewear]

title: lina_rei
body:
An alternative reality version of [[Ayanami Rei]] that appears in the final episode of [[Neon Genesis Evangelion]], [i]"The Beast that Shouted 'I' at the Heart of the World"[/i].

She appears in a different [[school uniform]] than normal (with a [[brown sweater vest|brown]] or [[yellow sweater vest]] , [[white shirt|white]] [[short sleeves|short-sleeved]] [[dress shirt]], [[red necktie]], and [[black skirt|black]] or [[grey skirt]]).

She also has a much more emotive and assertive personality than Rei typically has.  Because the [[scene reference|scene]] she appears in is a parody of the stereotypical "[[late for school|crash into the girl hurrying to get to school]]" meme, she is often depicted running with a piece of [[toast in mouth|toast in her mouth]].

Because Rei shares a voice actress with [[Lina Inverse]] from [[Slayers]] (which originally came out about the same time as Evangelion), and because this alternate version of Rei seemed to share Lina's personality and thus sounded very similar, the Japanese fan community nicknamed this version of her as "Lina Rei".

h4. Appearance

* !post #469854

h4. External links

* "Pixiv Encyclopedia: Lina Rei":[https://dic.pixiv.net/a/%E3%83%AA%E3%83%8A%E3%83%AC%E3%82%A4]

Sometimes these would be scientific demonstrations, sometimes elaborate choreographed performances (as was the original viral internet video), sometimes [[prank]]s.

The alter ego of [[Kajou Ayame]] from [[Shimoneta to Iu Gainen ga Sonzai Shinai Taikutsu na Sekai]].

When acting as this persona, she wears [[panties]] on her head either as [[panties on head|headwear]] or as a [[panty mask|a mask]], and a loose-fitting and free flowing [[bed sheet]] over her shoulders. She is typically depicted as being otherwise [[naked_sheet|naked underneath]]. She is also usually shown as being [[barefoot]] and without legwear.

title: styrofoam
body:
A material made of polystyrene with many embedded air pockets. It is lightweight and has good thermal insulation.

It is often used in packaging material (e.g. [[egg carton]]s, [[tray]]s used in [[food packaging]], [[take-out]] food containers; as a filler for shipping (such as as [[packing peanuts]]); or as a type of [[disposable cup]] for hot beverages (especially [[disposable coffee cup|coffee cup]]s).

title: light_gun
body:
A specialized [[game controller]], usually shaped like a [[gun]] and used to play target-shooting [[video game]]s.

The light gun is so called because in its earliest forms, it used light sensors inside the shell to track "hits" on the targets. Light guns have been popular in arcade games such as Time Crisis, Point Blank, Virtua Cop and House of the Dead. They have also been popular in early home console games such as Duck Hunt, in addition to more modern home ports of arcade classics.

Traditionally, light gun controllers have been wired and permanently connected on arcade games; their home counterparts were wired and unpluggable. Nowadays, home light guns use [[wireless]] Bluetooth connections.

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Light gun shooter":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_gun_shooter

title: suzume's_chair
body:
A particular yellow wooden children's [[chair]] belonging to [[Iwato Suzume]] in [[Suzume no Tojimari]], and possessed by [[Munakata Souta]] for much of the film.

This tag is for the object itself, whether or not it is currently possessed or animated.  If it is possessed by Souta (talking, walking, blushing, etc), then additionally use the tag [[Munakata Souta (Chair)]].  This chair appears in almost the entire film [[damaged]] with one leg missing. It has eyes carved into its backrest.

title: tendou_souun
body:
The widowed father of [[Tendou Akane|Akane]], [[Tendou Nabiki|Nabiki]] and [[Tendou Kasumi|Kasumi]] in [[Ranma 1/2]].

He is friends with [[Saotome Genma]] and trained alongside him under [[Happosai]]'s school of martial arts. He runs the Tendou Dojo, which houses most of the principal characters in the series.

He has [[long hair|long]] [[hair slicked back|slicked-back hair]], [[black eyes]], [[thick eyebrows]], prominent [[cheekbones]] and a [[mustache]].  He typically wears a [[brown kimono|brown]] [[kimono]].

title: egg_carton
body: A [[carton]] used for shipping, selling, and storing [[egg]]s. They are typically made of [[styrofoam]], [[cardboard]], or sometimes [[plastic]]. They typically hold 6, 12, or 18 eggs each (in the US), in Japan they may hold 10, 12, 24, or 30.

title: metal_wire
body:
Bare [[metal]] wire, as you might see  used structurally as a guy-wire, in a [[wire fence]], as a [[garrote]] wire, or similar.

For electricity-conducting insulated wires used in electronics, instead use e.g. [[wire]], [[cable]], or [[power lines]] as appropriate.

title: pokemon_(game)
body:
An umbrella tag for characters and/or situations of the [[pokemon|Pokémon]] video games.

Please specify further if possible by using game tags. For a list of game tags, see [[list of pokemon media|list of Pokémon media]].

h4. Characters

Most game characters have versions in other media (anime and manga). Sometimes, you can use this tag to search for the game version of a character, specifically. Examples of searches...

* {{misty_(pokemon) pokemon_(game)}}
* {{red_(pokemon) pokemon_(game)}}
* {{blue_oak pokemon_(game)}}

A few other character tags are strictly game-only. Examples: [[Mint (Pokemon)]], [[Wes (pokemon)|]].

h4. See also

* [[Pokemon (Anime)]]
* [[Pokemon Adventures]]
* [[List of Pokemon Media]]

title: sazae-san_food_gag_(meme)
body:
A [[meme]] wherein a character appears [[dancing]] in a split and hollowed out object (usually a [[fruit]], [[vegetable]], or other [[food]]), standing in the bottom half, and holding the upper half [[carrying_overhead|over their head]] in a "[[\o/]]" sort of pose.

This is [[parody|]]ing the end of the opening sequence of the long-running anime [[Sazae-san]], which since April 1971 has featured [[Fuguta Sazae|Fuguta Sazae's]] cat [[Tama (Sazae-san)|]] popping out of an fruit and dancing in this manner.  She and her whole family would also do so.  

The featured foods would also vary over time and with the seasons (e.g. a [[tomato]] and [[peewah]] for spring; [[watermelon]] and [[melon]] for summer; [[persimmon]] and [[chestnut]] for autumn; and an [[apple]] and [[mikan]] for winter).  An irregular version of the gag where Tama pops out early has been dubbed "フライングタマ" / "Flying Tama" in Japan.

An example of this gag in the OP with the family popping out of an apple and Tama popping out of a mikan can be seen "here":[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IUgxKutV_p0]. An example from April 1971 before the standardized seasonal fruit were set can be seen "here":[https://youtu.be/BW1XgYm_AiM?t=8], with Tama and the family both popping out of [[strawberry|strawberries]].

h4. External links

* "An article describing the Opening Gag (in Japanese)":[https://premium-goma.com/sazae-flyingtama/]
* "Initial appearance of the 'Flying Tama' variant of the gag in the Sazae-san opening":[https://twitter.com/Sazaesan_survey/status/1127562860714848261]

title: floorplan
body:
The inside of a room or building as seen from the outside from a cutaway, generally with furnishings and people.

Don't use this if there isn't at least the ceiling or a wall missing or if the room extends past the edges of the image. For top-down plans and cross-sections that look like architectural drawings, generally with no people, use [[layout plan]] instead.

* [[diorama]]

title: tangle_the_lemur
body:
Major character in the [[sonic the hedgehog (idw)|Sonic IDW comic series]]. A [[lemur girl]] with a long tail from Spiral Hill Village and the current leader of the modern incarnation of the Diamond Cutters. She was designed to be a [[tomboy]]ish adventure companion for [[sonic the hedgehog|Sonic]].

She is commonly paired with [[Whisper the Wolf]], and while the writers of the comics support the pairing, it can only be implied in canon rather than confirmed due to Sega mandates around romance.

She made her game debut in the mobile games [[Sonic Dash]] and [[Sonic Forces: Speed Battle]].

h4. External links
* "Sonic Wiki Zone: Tangle the Lemur":https://sonic.fandom.com/wiki/Tangle_the_Lemur
other_names: タングル・ザ・リーマー

title: whisper_the_wolf
body:
Major character in the [[sonic the hedgehog (idw)|Sonic IDW comic series]]. A soft-spoken [[wolf girl]] with trauma from her past in the original Diamond Cutters prior to the events of the series. She uses a special weapon designed to use the power of [[Wisp (sonic)|]]s.

She is commonly paired with [[Tangle the Lemur]], and while the writers of the comics support the pairing, it can only be implied in canon rather than confirmed due to Sega mandates around romance.

She made her game debut in the mobile games [[Sonic Dash]] and [[Sonic Forces: Speed Battle]].

h4. External links
* "Sonic Wiki Zone: Whisper the Wolf":https://sonic.fandom.com/wiki/Whisper_the_Wolf
